titleStmt.title: A new iterative method for equilibrium problems and fixed point problems of nonexpansive mappings and monotone mappings q

analytic.title: A new iterative method for equilibrium problems and fixed point problems of nonexpansive mappings and monotone mappings q

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, we introduce a new iterative scheme for finding the common element of the set of fixed points of a nonexpansive mapping, the set of solutions of an equilibrium problem and the set of solutions of the variational inequality for a-inverse-strongly monotone mappings. We show that the sequence converges strongly to a common element of the above three sets under some parameters controlling conditions. This main theorem extends a recent result of Yao and Yao [Y. Yao, J.-C. Yao, On modified iterative method for nonexpansive mappings and monotone mappings, Applied Mathematics and Computation 186 (2) (2007) 1551-1558].

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Let H be a real Hilbert space with inner product hAE, AEi and norm kAEk, respectively and let C be a closed convex subset of H. Let F be a bifunction of C • C into R, where R is the set of real numbers. The equilibrium problem for F : C Â C ! R is to find x 2 C such that F ðx; yÞ P 0 for all y 2 C: ð1:1Þ

The set of solutions of (1.1) is denoted by EP(F). Given a mapping T : C ! H , let F ðx; yÞ ¼ hTx; y À xi for all x, y 2 C. Then z 2 EP(F) if and only if hTz, y À zi P 0 for all y 2 C, i.e., z is a solution of the variational inequality. Numerous problems in physics, optimization, and economics reduce to find a solution of (1.1).
In 1997 Combettes and Hirstoaga [3] introduced an iterative scheme of finding the best approximation to initial data when EP(F) is nonempty and proved a strong convergence theorem.

Let A : C ! H be a mapping. The classical variational inequality, denoted by VIðA; CÞ, is to find x * 2 C such that hAx Ã ; v À x Ã i P 0 for all v 2 C. The variational inequality has been extensively studied in the literature. See, e.g. [12,14] and the references therein. A mapping A of C into H is called a-inverse-strongly monotone [2,4] if there exists a positive real number a such that hAu À Av; u À vi P akAu À Avk 2 for all u, v 2 C. It is obvious that any a-inverse-strongly monotone mapping A is monotone and Lipschitz continuous. A mapping S of C into itself is called nonexpansive if kSu À Svk 6 ku À vk for all u, v 2 C. We denote by F(S) the set of fixed points of S. For finding an element of F ðSÞ \ VIðA; CÞ, Takahashi and Toyoda [9] introduced the following iterative scheme:
div.formula: x nþ1 ¼ a n x n þ ð1 À a n ÞSP C ðx n À k n Ax n Þ ð 1:2Þ
div.p: for every n = 0, 1, 2, . . . , where x 0 = x 2 C, a n is a sequence in (0, 1), and k n is a sequence in (0, 2a). Recently, Nadezhkina and Takahashi [5] and Zeng and Yao [15] proposed some new iterative schemes for finding elements in F ðSÞ \ VIðA; CÞ. In 2006, Yao and Yao [13] introduced the following iterative scheme: Let C be a closed convex subset of real Hilbert space H. Let A be an a-inverse-strongly monotone mapping of C into H and let S be a nonexpansive mapping of C into itself such that F ðSÞ \ VIðA; CÞ 6 ¼ ;. Suppose x 1 = u 2 C and {x n }, {y n } are given by
div.formula: y n ¼ P C ðx n À k n Ax n Þ; x nþ1 ¼ a n u þ b n x n þ c n SP C ðy n À k n Ay n Þ; ð1:3Þ
div.p: where {a n }, {b n }, {c n } are three sequences in [0, 1] and {k n } is a sequence in ½0; 2a. They proved that the sequence {x n } defined by (1.3) converges strongly to common element of the set of fixed points of a nonexpansive mapping and the set of solutions of the variational inequality for a-inverse-strongly monotone mappings under some parameters controlling conditions. Moreover, Takahashi and Takahashi [8] introduced an iterative scheme by the viscosity approximation method for finding a common element of the set of solutions of an equilibrium problem and the set of fixed points of a nonexpansive mapping in a Hilbert space. They also proved a strong convergence theorem which is connected with Combettes and Hirstoaga's result [3] and Wittmann's result [10].

In this paper motivated by the iterative schemes considered in [8,13] we will introduce a new iterative process (3.1) below for finding a common element of the set of fixed points of a nonexpansive mapping, the set of solutions of an equilibrium problem, and the solution set of the variational inequality problem for an ainverse-strongly monotone mapping in a real Hilbert space. Then, we prove a strong convergence theorem which is connected with Yao and Yao's result [13] and Takahashi and Takahashi's result [8].

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: Let H be a real Hilbert space with norm kAEk and inner product hAE, AEi and let C be a closed convex subset of H. For every point x 2 H, there exists a unique nearest point in C, denoted by P C x, such that kx À P C xk 6 kx À yk for all y 2 C: The following lemmas will be useful for proving the convergence result of this paper.
div.formula: P C is
div.p: Lemma 2.1 [6]. Let (E, hAE,AEi) be an inner product space. Then for all x, y, z 2 E and a, b, c
div.formula: 2 [0, 1] with a + b + c = 1, we have kax þ by þ czk 2 ¼ akxk 2 þ bkyk 2 þ ckzk 2 À abkx À yk 2 À ackx À zk 2 À bcky À zk 2 :
div.p: Lemma 2.2 [7]. Let {x n } and {y n } be bounded sequences in a Banach space X and let {b n } be a sequence in
div.formula: [0, 1] with 0 < lim inf n!1 b n 6 lim sup n!1 b n < 1. Suppose x n+1 = (1 À b n )y n + b n
div.p: x n for all integers n P 0 and
div.formula: lim sup n!1 ðky n þ 1 À y n k À kx n þ 1 À x n kÞ 6 0. Then, lim n!1 ky n À x n k = 0.
div.p: Lemma 2.3. Let H be a Hilbert space, C a closed convex subset of H, and T : C ! C a nonexpansive mapping with F(T) 5 ;. If {x n } is a sequence in C weakly converging to x 2 C and if {(I À T)x n } converges strongly to y, then (I À T)x = y.
Lemma 2.4 [11]. Assume {a n } is a sequence of nonnegative real numbers such that
div.formula: a nþ1 6 ð1 À a n Þa n þ d n ; n P 0;
div.p: where {a n } is a sequence in (0, 1) and {d n } is a sequence in R such that
lim sup n!1 dn an 6 0 or P 1 n¼1 jd n j < 1:
div.formula: Then lim n!1 a n ¼ 0.
div.p: For solving the equilibrium problem for a bifunction F : C Â C ! R, let us assume that F satisfies the following conditions: (A1) F ðx; xÞ ¼ 0 for all x 2 C; (A2) F is monotone, i.e., F ðx; yÞ þ F ðy; xÞ 6 0 for all x, y 2 C; (A3) for each x, y, z 2 C, lim t!0 F ðtz þ ð1 À tÞx; yÞ 6 F ðx; yÞ; (A4) for each x 2 C; y 7 ! F ðx; yÞ is convex and lower semicontinuous.
The following lemma appears implicitly in [1].
Lemma 2.5 [1]. Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of H and let F be a bifunction of C • C into R satisfying (A1)-(A4). Let r > 0 and x 2 H. Then, there exists z 2 C such that
div.formula: F ðz; yÞ þ 1 r hy À z; z À xi P 0 f or all y 2 C:
div.p: The following lemma was also given in [3].
Lemma 2.6 [3]. Assume that F : C Â C ! R satisfies (A1)-(A4). For r > 0 and x 2 H, define a mapping T r : H ! C as follows:
div.formula: T r ðxÞ ¼ z 2 C : F ðz; yÞ þ 1 r hy À z; z À xi P 0; 8y 2 C
div.p: for all z 2 H. Then, the following hold:
1. T r is single-valued; 2. T r is firmly nonexpansive, i.e., for any x, y 2 H, kT r x À T r yk 2 6 hT r x À T r y, x À yi; 3. F(T r ) = EP(F); 4. EP(F) is closed and convex.

div.head: Main results
div.p: In this section, we prove strong convergence theorems
div.formula: F ðu n ; yÞ þ 1 rn hy À u n ; u n À x n i P 0; 8y 2 C; y n ¼ P C ðu n À k n Au n Þ; x nþ1 ¼ a n u þ b n x n þ c n SP C ðy n À k n Ay n Þ
(i) a n + b n + c n = 1, (ii) lim n!1 a n ¼ 0; P 1 n¼1 a n ¼ 1; (iii) 0 < lim inf n!1 b n 6 lim sup n!1 b n < 1, (iv) lim inf n!1 r n > 0; P 1 n¼1 jr nþ1 À r n j < 1; (v) lim n!1 (k n+1 À k n ) = 0,
div.p: then {x n } converges strongly to P F ðSÞ\VIðA;CÞ\EP ðF Þ u:
Proof. For all x, y 2 C and k n 2 ½0; 2a; we note that
div.formula: kðI À k n AÞx À ðI À k n AÞyk 2 ¼ kðx À yÞ À k n ðAx À AyÞk 2 ¼ kx À yk 2 À 2k n hx À y; Ax À Ayi þ k 2 n kAx À Ayk 2 6 kx À yk 2 þ k n ðk n À 2aÞkAx À Ayk 2 ; ð3:2Þ which implies that I À k n A is nonexpansive. Let x * 2 F(S) \ VI(A, C) \ EP(F)
div.p: , and let fT rn g be a sequence of mappings defined as in Lemma 2.6. Then
div.formula: x Ã ¼ P C ðx Ã À k n Ax Ã Þ ¼ T rn x Ã . Put v n = P C (y n À k n Ay n ). From (3.2), we note that kv n À x Ã k ¼ kP C ðy n À k n Ay n Þ À P C ðx Ã À k n Ax Ã Þk 6 kðy n À k n Ay n Þ À ðx Ã À k n Ax Ã Þk 6 ky n À x Ã k ¼ kP C ðu n À k n Au n Þ À P C ðx Ã À k n Ax Ã Þk 6 kðu n À k n Au n Þ À ðx Ã À k n Ax Ã Þk 6 ku n À x Ã k ¼ kT rn x n À T rn x Ã k 6 kx n À x Ã k: ð3:3Þ
div.p: Thus, we have
div.formula: kx nþ1 À x Ã k ¼ ka n u þ b n x n þ c n Sv n À x Ã k 6 a n ku À x Ã k þ b n kx n À x Ã k þ c n kv n À x Ã k 6 a n ku À x Ã k þ b n kx n À x Ã k þ c n kx n À x Ã k ¼ a n ku À x Ã k þ ð1 À a n Þkx n À x Ã k 6 maxfku À x Ã k; kx 1 À x Ã kg ¼ ku À x Ã k:
div.p: Therefore {x n } is bounded. Consequently, the sets {u n }, {v n }, {Sv n }, {Au n } and {Ay n } are also bounded. Moreover, we observe that
div.formula: kv nþ1 À v n k ¼ kP C ðy nþ1 À k nþ1 Ay nþ1 Þ À P C ðy n À k n Ay n Þk 6 kðy nþ1 À k nþ1 Ay nþ1 Þ À ðy n À k n Ay n Þk ¼ kðy nþ1 À k nþ1 Ay nþ1 Þ À ðy n À k nþ1 Ay n Þ þ ðk n À k nþ1 ÞAy n k 6 kðy nþ1 À k nþ1 Ay nþ1 Þ À ðy n À k nþ1 Ay n Þk þ jk n À k nþ1 jkAy n k 6 ky nþ1 À y n k þ jk n À k nþ1 jkAy n k ¼ kP C ðu nþ1 À k nþ1 Au nþ1 Þ À P C ðu n À k n Au n Þk þ jk n À k nþ1 jkAy n k 6 kðu nþ1 À k nþ1 Au nþ1 Þ À ðu n À k n Au n Þk þ jk n À k nþ1 jkAy n k ¼ kðu nþ1 À k nþ1 Au nþ1 Þ À ðu n À k nþ1 Au n Þ þ ðk n À k nþ1 ÞAu n k þ jk n À k nþ1 jkAy n k 6 kðI À k nþ1 AÞu nþ1 À ðI À k nþ1 AÞu n k þ jk n À k nþ1 jðkAu n k þ kAy n kÞ 6 ku nþ1 À u n k þ jk n À k nþ1 jðkAu n k þ kAy n kÞ:
div.p: On the other hand, from u n ¼ T rn x n and u nþ1 ¼ T r nþ1 x nþ1 , we note that
div.formula: F ðu n ; yÞ þ 1 r n hy À u n ; u n À x n i P 0 for all y 2 C ð3:4Þand
F ðu nþ1 ; yÞ þ 1 r nþ1
div.p: hy À u nþ1 ; u nþ1 À x nþ1 i P 0 for all y 2 C: ð3:5Þ
Putting y = u n+1 in (3.4) and y = u n in (3.5), we have
div.formula: F ðu n ; u nþ1 Þ þ 1 r n hu nþ1 À u n ; u n À x n i P 0 and F ðu nþ1 ; u n Þ þ 1 r nþ1
div.p: hu n À u nþ1 ; u nþ1 À x nþ1 i P 0:
So, from (A2) we have
div.formula: u nþ1 À u n ; u n À x n r n À u nþ1 À x nþ1 r nþ1 P 0
div.p: and hence
div.formula: u nþ1 À u n ; u n À u nþ1 þ u nþ1 À x n À r n r nþ1 ðu nþ1 À x nþ1 Þ P 0:
div.p: Without loss of generality, let us assume that there exists a real number c such that r n > c > 0 for all n 2 N. Then, we have
div.formula: ku nþ1 À u n k 2 6 u nþ1 À u n ; x nþ1 À x n þ 1 À r n r nþ1 ðu nþ1 À x nþ1 Þ 6 ku nþ1 À u n k kx nþ1 À x n k þ 1 À r n r nþ1 ku nþ1 À x nþ1 k
div.p: and hence
div.formula: ku nþ1 À u n k 6 kx nþ1 À x n k þ 1 r nþ1 jr nþ1 À r n jku nþ1 À x nþ1 k 6 kx nþ1 À x n k þ 1 c jr nþ1 À r n jL; ð3:6Þ
div.p: where L ¼ supfku n À x n k : n 2 Ng. Hence, we have
div.formula: kv nþ1 À v n k 6 ku nþ1 À u n k þ jk n À k nþ1 jðkAu n k þ kAy n kÞ 6 kx nþ1 À x n k þ 1 c jr nþ1 À r n jL þ jk n À k nþ1 jðkAu n k þ kAy n kÞ: ð3:7Þ Let x n+1 = (1 À b n )z n + b n x n .
div.p: Thus, we note that
div.formula: z n ¼ x nþ1 À b n x n 1 À b n ¼ a n u þ c n SP C ðy n À k n Ay n Þ 1 À b n ¼ a n u þ c n Sv n 1 À b n
div.p: and hence we have
div.formula: z nþ1 À z n ¼ a nþ1 u þ c nþ1 Sv nþ1 1 À b nþ1 À a n u þ c n Sv n 1 À b n ¼ a nþ1 u þ c nþ1 Sv nþ1 1 À b nþ1 À a nþ1 u þ c nþ1 Sv n 1 À b nþ1 þ a nþ1 u þ c nþ1 Sv n 1 À b nþ1 À a n u þ c n Sv n 1 À b n ¼ a nþ1 1 À b nþ1 À a n 1 À b n u þ c nþ1 1 À b nþ1 ðSv nþ1 À Sv n Þ þ c nþ1 1 À b nþ1 À c n 1 À b n Sv n :
div.p: ð3:8Þ
Combining (3.7) and (3.8), we have
div.formula: kz nþ1 À z n k À kx nþ1 À x n k 6 a nþ1 1 À b nþ1 À a n 1 À b n kuk þ c nþ1 1 À b nþ1 kv nþ1 À v n k þ c nþ1 1 À b nþ1 À c n 1 À b n kSv n k À kx nþ1 À x n k 6 a nþ1 1 À b nþ1 À a n 1 À b n kuk þ c nþ1 1 À b nþ1 kx nþ1 À x n k þ c nþ1 ð1 À b nþ1 Þc jr nþ1 À r n jL þ c nþ1 1 À b nþ1 jk n À k nþ1 jðkAu n k þ kAy n kÞ þ c nþ1 1 À b nþ1 À c n 1 À b n kSv n k À kx nþ1 À x n k 6 a nþ1 1 À b nþ1 À a n 1 À b n ðkuk þ kSv n kÞ þ c nþ1 ð1 À b nþ1 Þc jr nþ1 À r n jL þ c nþ1 1 À b nþ1 jk n À k nþ1 jðkAu n k þ kAy n kÞ:
div.p: This together with (ii), (iv) and (v) imply that lim sup n!1 ðkz nþ1 À z n k À kx nþ1 À x n kÞ 6 0:
Hence, by Lemma 2.2, we obtain kz n À x n k ! 0 as n ! 1. Consequently,
div.formula: lim n!1 kx nþ1 À x n k ¼ lim n!1 ð1 À b n Þkz n À x n k ¼ 0: ð3:9Þ
div.p: From (iv), (v), (3.7) and (3.9), we also have kv n+1 À v n k ! 0, ku n+1 À u n k ! 0 and ky n+1 À y n k ! 0 as n ! 1. Since
div.formula: x nþ1 À x n ¼ a n u þ b n x n þ c n Sv n À x n ¼ a n ðu À x n Þ þ c n ðSv n À x n Þ;
div.p: it follows by (ii) and (3.9) that kx n À Sv n k ! 0 as n ! 1. For x Ã 2 F ðSÞ \ VIðA; CÞ \ EP ðF Þ, we have
div.formula: ku n À x Ã k 2 ¼ kT rn x n À T rn x Ã k 2 6 hT rn x n À T rn x Ã ; x n À x Ã i ¼ hu n À x Ã ; x n À x Ã i ¼ 1 2 ðku n À x Ã k 2 þ kx n À x Ã k 2 À kx n À u n k 2 Þ and hence ku n À x * k 2 6 kx n À x * k 2 À kx n À u n k 2 . From (3.
div.p: 3), we obtain
div.formula: kx nþ1 À x Ã k 2 ¼ ka n u þ b n x n þ c n Sv n À x Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n kSv n À x Ã k
div.p: and hence
div.formula: c n kx n À u n k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ kx n À x Ã k 2 À kx nþ1 À x Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ kx n À x nþ1 kðkx n À x Ã k þ kx nþ1 À x Ã kÞ; ð3:11Þ
div.p: since a n ! 0 and (3.9) imply that ku n À x n k ! 0 as n ! 1.
From Lemma 2.1, (3.2), (3.3), and (3.10) we get
div.formula: kx nþ1 À x Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n kv n À x Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n ky n À x Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n fkðu n À k n Au n Þ À ðx Ã À k n Ax Ã Þk 2 g 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n fku n À x Ã k 2 þ k n ðk n À 2aÞkAu n À Ax Ã k 2 g ¼ a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n k n ðk n À 2aÞkAu n À Ax Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n aðb À 2aÞkAu n À Ax Ã k 2 :
div.p: Therefore, we have
div.formula: Àc n aðb À 2aÞkAu n À Ax Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ kx n À x Ã k 2 À kx nþ1 À x Ã k 2 ¼ a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ ðkx n À x Ã k þ kx nþ1 À x Ã kÞ Â ðkx n À x Ã k À kx nþ1 À x Ã kÞ 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ ðkx n À x Ã k þ kx nþ1 À x Ã kÞ Â kx n À x nþ1 k: ð3:12Þ
div.p: Since a n ! 0 and kx n À x n+1 k ! 0 as n ! 1, from (3.12), we obtain kAu n À Ax * k ! 0 as n ! 1. From (2.1), we have
div.formula: ky n À x Ã k 2 ¼ kP C ðu n À k n Au n Þ À P C ðx Ã À k n Ax Ã Þk 2 6 hðu n À k n Au n Þ À ðx Ã À k n Ax Ã Þ; y n À x Ã i ¼ 1 2 kðu n À k n Au n Þ À ðx Ã À k n Ax Ã Þk 2 þ ky n À x Ã k 2 À kðu n À k n Au n Þ n À x Ã À k n Ax Ã Þ À ðy n À x Ã Þk 2 o 6 1 2 ku n À x Ã k 2 þ ky n À x Ã k 2 À kðu n À y n Þ À k n ðAu n À Ax Ã Þk 2 n o ¼ 1 2 ku n À x Ã k 2 þ ky n À x Ã k 2 À ku n À y n k 2 þ 2k n hu n À y n ; Au n À Ax Ã i À k 2 n kAu n À Ax Ã k 2
div.p: n o so, we obtain
div.formula: ky n À x Ã k 2 6 ku n À x Ã k 2 À ku n À y n k 2 þ 2k n hu n À y n ; Au n À Ax Ã i À k 2 n kAu n À Ax Ã k 2 :
div.p: Hence
div.formula: kx nþ1 À x Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n kv n À x Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n ky n À x Ã k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n fku n À x Ã k 2 À ku n À y n k 2 þ 2k n hu n À y n ; Au n À Ax Ã i À k 2 n kAu n À Ax Ã k 2 g 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ b n kx n À x Ã k 2 þ c n kx n À x Ã k 2 À ku n À y n k 2 þ 2k n hu n À y n ; Au n À Ax Ã i À k 2 n kAu n À Ax Ã k 2 n o 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ kx n À x Ã k 2 À c n ku n À y n k 2 þ 2c n k n ku n À y n kkAu n À Ax Ã k; which implies that c n ku n À y n k 2 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ kx n À x Ã k 2 À kx nþ1 À x Ã k 2 þ 2c n k n ku n À y n kkAu n À Ax Ã k 6 a n ku À x Ã k 2 þ 2c n k n ku n À y n kkAu n À Ax Ã k þ kx n À x nþ1 k Â ðkx n À x Ã k þ kx nþ1 À x Ã kÞk: ð3:13Þ From (3.13), a n ! 0, kx n À x n+1 k ! 0 and kAu n À Ax * k ! 0 as n ! 1, we have ku n À y n k ! 0 as n ! 1. Since kSv n À v n k 6 kSv n À x n k þ kx n À u n k þ ku n À y n k þ ky n À v n k ¼ kSv n À x n k þ kx n À u n k þ ku n À y n k þ kP C ðu n À k n Au n Þ À P C ðy n À k n Ay n Þk 6 kSv n À x n k þ kx n À u n k þ ku n À y n k þ kðu n À k n Au n Þ À ðy n À k n Ay n Þk 6 kSv n À x n k þ kx n À u n k þ 2ku n À y n k; we get kSv n À v n k ! 0 as n ! 1. Hence kv n À y n k 6 kv n À Sv n k þ kSv n À x n k þ kx n À u n k þ ku n À y n k ! 0; n ! 1: Next, we show that lim sup n!1 hu À z 0 ; x n À z 0 i 6 0;
div.p: where z 0 = P F(S)\VI(A,C)\EP(F) (u). To show this inequality, we choose a subsequence fv ni g of {v n } such that lim sup From ku n À x n k ! 0, kx n À Sv n k ! 0, and kSv n À v n k ! 0, we get u ni * z. Since u n i Àx n i r n i ! 0; it follows by (A4) that 0 P F ðy; zÞ for all y 2 C. For t with 0 < t 6 1 and y 2 C, let y t = ty + (1 À t)z. Since y 2 C and z 2 C, we have y t 2 C and hence F ðy t ; zÞ 6 0. So, from (A1) and (A4) we have 0 ¼ F ðy t ; y t Þ 6 tF ðy t ; yÞ þ ð1 À tÞF ðy t ; zÞ 6 tF ðy t ; yÞ and hence 0 6 F ðy t ; yÞ. From (A3), we have 0 6 F ðz; yÞ for all y 2 C and hence z 2 EP(F). By the opial's condition, we obtain z 2 F(S). Finally, by the same argument as that in the proof of [5,Theorem 3.1,, we can show that z 2 VIðA; CÞ. Hence z 2 F(S) \ VI(A, C) \ EP(F). Now from (2.2), we have lim sup

div.head: Applications
div.p: Using Theorem 3.1, we prove three theorems in Hilbert space.

Theorem 4.1 (Yao and Yao [13,Theorem 3.1]). Let C be a closed convex subset of a real Hilbert space H. Let A be an a-inverse-strongly monotone mapping of C into H and let S be a nonexpansive mapping of C into itself such that F ðSÞ \ VIðA; CÞ 6 ¼ ;. Suppose x 1 = u 2 C and {x n }, {y n } are given by

where {a n }, {b n }, {c n } are three sequences in [0, 1] and {k n } is a sequence in [0, 2a]. If {a n }, {b n }, {c n } and {k n } are chosen so that k n 2 [a, b] for some a, b with 0 < a < b < 2a and

then {x n } converges strongly to P F ðSÞ\VIðA;CÞ u: Proof. Put F ðx; yÞ ¼ 0 for all x, y 2 C and r n = 1 for all n 2 N in Theorem 3.1. Then, we have u n = P C x n = x n . So, from Theorem 3.1 the sequence {x n } generated in Theorem 4.1 converges strongly to P F ðSÞ\VIðA;CÞ u: h A mapping T : C ! C is called strictly pseudocontractive on C if there exists k with 0 6 k < 1 such that
for all x; y 2 C:

Hence we have

Then, A is 1Àk 2 -inverse strongly monotone. Now, using Theorem 3.1, we state a strong convergence theorem for a pair of a nonexpansive mapping and strictly pseudocontractive mapping. Theorem 4.2. Let C be a closed convex subset of a real Hilbert space H. Let F be a bifunction from C • C ! R satisfying (A1)-(A4) and let S be a nonexpansive mapping of C into itself and let T be a strictly pseudocontractive mapping with constant k of C into itself such that F(S) \ F(T) \ EP(F) 5 ;. Suppose x 1 = u 2 C and {x n }, {y n } and {u n } are given by

for all n 2 N, where {a n }, {b n }, {c n } are three sequences in [0, 1] and {k n } is a sequence in ½0; 1 À k. If {a n }, {b n }, {c n } and {k n } are chosen so that k n 2 ½a; b for some a, b with 0 < a < b < 1 À k and fr n g & ð0; 1Þ satisfying
then {x n } converges strongly to P F(S)\F(T)\EP(F) u.
Proof. Put A = I À T. Then A is 1Àk 2 -inverse-strongly monotone. We have that F(T) is the solution set of VIðA; CÞ i.e., F ðT Þ ¼ VIðA; CÞ and

Therefore, by Theorem 3.1, the conclusion follows. h Corollary 4.3 (Yao and Yao 13, Theorem 3.3). Let C be a closed convex subset of a real Hilbert space H. Let S be a nonexpansive mapping of C into itself and let T be a strictly pseudocontractive mapping with constant k of C into itself such that F(S) \ F(T) 5 ;. Suppose x 1 = u 2 C and {x n } is given by

for all n 2 N, where {a n }, {b n }, {c n } are three sequences in [0, 1] and {k n } is a sequence in ½0; 1 À k. If {a n }, {b n }, {c n } and {k n } are chosen so that k n 2 ½a; b for some a, b with 0 < a < b < 1 À k and
then {x n } converges strongly to P F(S)\F(T) u.

Proof. Put F ðx; yÞ ¼ 0 for all x, y 2 C, r n = 1 for all n 2 N and A = I À T, we get u n = P C x n = x n and A is 1Àk 2inverse-strongly monotone. We have that F(T) is the solution set of VIðA; CÞ i.e., F ðT Þ ¼ VIðA; CÞ and

Therefore, by Theorem 3.1, the conclusion follows. h Theorem 4.4. Let H be a real Hilbert space. Let F be a bifunction from H • H ! R satisfying (A1)-(A4) and let A be an a-inverse-strongly monotone mapping of H into itself and let S be a nonexpansive mapping of H into itself such that F(S) \ A À1 (0) \ EP(F) 5 ;. Suppose x 1 = u 2 H and {x n }, {y n } and {u n } are given by

for all n 2 N, where {a n }, {b n }, {c n } are three sequences in [0, 1] and {k n } is a sequence in [0, 2a]. If {a n }, {b n }, {c n } and {k n } are chosen so that k n 2 [a, b] for some a, b with 0 < a < b < 2a and {r n } & (0, 1) satisfying (i) a n + b n + c n = 1, (ii) lim n!1 a n ¼ 0; P 1 n¼1 a n ¼ 1, (iii) 0 < liminf n!1 b n 6 limsup n!1 b n < 1, (iv) lim inf n!1 r n > 0; P 1 n¼1 jr nþ1 À r n j < 1, (v) lim n!1 (k n+1 À k n ) = 0, then {x n } converges strongly to P F ðSÞ\A À1 ð0Þ\EP ðF Þ u:
Proof. Since A À1 (0) is the solution set of VIðA; H Þ; we can obtain the conclusion by Theorem 3.1 and by noting that P H is the identity mapping on H. This completes the proof. h
